newsitem.title: UK: Magnets could help kill pain - magazine.
newsitem.headline: Magnets could help kill pain - magazine.

text.p: Magnetic fields may be able to enhance the effects of painkillers like morphine by affecting brain chemistry, Canadian scientists say.
New Scientist magazine reported on Thursday researchers at the University of Western Ontario had found snails reacted more strongly to morphine when they were dosed inside a magnetic field.
Frank Prato and colleagues experimented with snails by putting them on a warm plate. The creatures normally reacted after about five seconds, looking for a cooler place.
But with an injection of morphine they tolerated the warm plate for up to three times longer.
The researchers said magnetic fields -- known to influence an animal's ability to navigate -- could also influence brain chemicals such as potassium and calcium.
Intensity and direction of the magnetic field changed the effects, sometimes sharply reducing them. "I found it an astonishing result," Prato was quoted by the magazine as saying.
